item.title: Temple of Chaos Devlog 2
item.description: The Plan In last week’s devlog, I was able to add a multiplayer menu, lobby, and ready up system to my old game jam project, Temple of Chaos. item.content:
The Plan

In last week’s devlog, I was able to add a multiplayer menu, lobby, and ready up system to my old game jam project, Temple of Chaos. This week, I would like to continue adding multiplayer to the game. I am going to be using Mirror and Steamworks Fizzy. Like I said last time, this is my first time making a multiplayer game with steamworks, so a lot of this is a learning experience. The plan is that I’m going to try to get player movement synced over the network, after that I’m going to start looking into how single-player works in am multiplayer game to see if I can reuse my multiplayer code. If I have time, I am going to try to get to get projectiles to sync of the network.

Daily Log

Monday

Today, I had to stay late at work to get some stuff done for an upcoming deadline. When I got home, I decided to take a bit of a mental break by laying down and watching some youtube. Once I was feeling a bit better, I got up and finished up the devlog from last week and then made some edits to the website. Its quite late now, but I’m going to try to start working on player movement.

I took my awhile to figure out how I was going to spawn the players and get them into the next scene. I ended up overriding the change scene method in the network manager to destroy the objects that I was using as player objects in the lobby and spawn new player objects for the in game players. After this I had to strip down my existing player prefab to be only player movement because changing the player movement script to a duplicate script that adds the necessary logic for multiplayer broke other scripts attached to the player. High coupling and low cohesion in a dream. I think its working, but I realized I need to make a new steam account and setup the project on my laptop if I want to test it. So I’m going to bed.

Tuesday

I woke up and had a nice cup of coffee. I got up and started working on testing… Just kidding :). After I a late night of programming, I woke up late for work. Luckily its not a huge deal if I’m a little bit late to my current job. Also, I know this isn’t like the glamorous, I just really love game dev and programming log right now but I figure its best to just be authenticate. I’m tired and sometimes programming makes me feel like I have no idea what I’m doing even after year of experience and a degree.

That said, I was talking with Jamac, the other developer that worked on the game jam version of the game with me, about the progress I was making on the project and it really lifted my spirits. He said he could hop on a call to help me test once we both got home from work. It didn’t work. There were a lot of bugs. My plan is to setup my laptop for testing the project, and then I’m going to iron out all of the bugs so that I can see if player movement is working or not.

I finally got the loading into the test multiplayer scene and network synced player movement working. It was most just a lot of configuring and then some small code changes.

Here is a clip of spawning into the multiplayer test scene and moving around. I only have the video from desktop player’s perspective but the other player is the game running on my laptop. I also made these little capsule models so we can see the other players moving around.

There is still a small bug where it looks like a player joins a lobby twice or something… Its not game breaking but it does throw an error and cause the editor to pause. I’m going to try to work that out.

Wednesday

I wasn’t keep up with my devlog, so this is future me say… I’m not exactly sure what I did this day. I think I took a break because I was a bit tired from work.

Side note, I did start working on a portfolio section of the site during my lunch break. Hopefully I can add that soon to display my work in one place.

Thursday

I worked on making interfaces for a lot of the original scripts in the game. Some of the singleplayer code is reusable, but I it references code that I had to rewrote for multiplayer, so I hade to make interfaces for almost everything I referenced. This was all in the hope of getting projectiles working in the multiplayer scene.

Also, at some point in this process I decided that I wanted to import the existing lighting and level geometry into the multiplayer scene. I think this was mostly because I needed a motivation boost after writing all of these interfaces and having no progress to visual show for it. Here is what that looks like

Friday

I decided to participate in the GMTK 2022 Game Jam so Temple of Chaos went on pause for the weekend. I’m going to talk about my experience with the jam here because I don’t think I have enough to say about for merit its own post. I worked with Jamac (James Dumas) and Josh Hovis on this game. James was the main programmer, Josh was the artist, and I was the sort of guy who did a lot of the levels, the menu systems, and I did decent amount of programming try my best to avoid conflicting with Jamac. Our game was a dice rolling puzzle game sort of inspired by bloxorz. It was a lot of fun, just like game jams in the past, though I was a little sad because on of our teammates had covid, we we had to do it from home instead of meeting up a central location. As always, it left me exhausted on Sunday and that carried into Monday. That said we did a pretty good job on getting sleep, I just think having your brain fire on all clinders for 16+ hours a day is a lot. I will leave a link to our game here.

Saturday

Game Jam.

Sunday

Game Jam and nap time after the game jam ended.

item.title: Temple of Chaos Devlog 1
item.description: The Plan I have been out of the project for a couple of weeks, so the first step is to figure out where I finished off and what is next. After investigating Github and Trello, I realized that I just finished updating the Unity Editor Version, updating the project to the Universal Render Pipeline, and updating to the new Unity Input System. I also did some general code clean up. I am going to stop there on cleanup and updating for now, and create a release as this point.
item.content:
The Plan

I have been out of the project for a couple of weeks, so the first step is to figure out where I finished off and what is next. After investigating Github and Trello, I realized that I just finished updating the Unity Editor Version, updating the project to the Universal Render Pipeline, and updating to the new Unity Input System. I also did some general code clean up. I am going to stop there on cleanup and updating for now, and create a release as this point.

After creating this release, my plan is to start prototyping multiplayer into the game. I think playing this with friends will give it the same vibes as grinding COD Zombies or Risk of Rain 2 with the boys. Its the way I like to enjoy these types of games. Because of that, I want to make sure I design the game to be multiplayer friendly so that I don’t push to far, and then realize that it would be to much to add multiplayer it in the future. My hope is that this will take about 2 weeks to finish with the current size of the game.My first step in setting up a multiplayer prototype is going to be getting the lobby screen working. I am going to be using Mirror and Steamworks Fizzy. This is my first time making a multiplayer game using steamworks. Fingers crossed that it goes smoothly.

I have also decided to go closed source with the game moving forward. My hope is that I can eventually sell this game, and I don’t want people compiling from source and redistrubuting. That said, my hope is that some amount of time after release I would like to release the source code for modding and port, etc. I will also keep the source code open source for what I have done up until this point. As I don’t want to yank it down. Its just anything moving forward will not be publish to that repository.

Daily Log

Monday

Did nothing. It was vacation day :-)

Tuesday

Was feeling a little under the weather, so I took another day to myself.

Wednesday

I wrote code off and on from 5pm to midnight. I was having trouble focusing. That said, I was able to implement a simple lobby system following this Youtube Tutorial made by Zyger . I then got names and profile pictures to show up on the lobby screen. I still need to test if other people can join since I do not have 2 steam accounts. I’m hoping to clean up the lobby UI and then move on to a ready up system tomorrow.

Thursday

So I started today by cleaning up the UI elements I made yesterday. A lot of scaling issues and edge cases I tried to fix. I also added a multiplayer button to the game’s existing main menu to take you to the multiplayer testing menu so now I can compile the game and send it to people for testing. Its around 9pm, I just ate dinner, and I’m going to try to finish the ready up system before I got to bed.

I got the ready up system working. It was easier than I thought now that I have a good foundation. I also took the time the style the UI to look more like the existing menu in the game. Its not final, but I had a little time and it made me feel like I got a win.

Friday

I went out with a friend from high school after work so I didn’t work on the game.

Saturday

I spent the day preparing for my move that is coming up in the next month. No work this day.

Sunday

I spend the day with my Girlfriend, so no more work.

Wrap Up

Honestly, I was hope that I would be able to get a little more done this week. I don’t think I will make my two week goal at this pace xD. That said, I’m happy that I was able to get the lobby system up and working. I think that making any progress I can helps keep the project going. I hope next week that I can start working on porting the player movement to support multiplayer. After this, I want to see if I can still use the multiplayer movement to play the game single-player offline or if I need to have need to find a way to reuse code between multiplayer fps controller and single-player fps controller. I think that will take up most of next week, but maybe I can also start on projectiles as well.

item.title: How to Create and Host A Blog Site for Free
item.description: If you have some development skills, and are looking to create a blog site for free, this is the place for you. I am going to walk through the steps I took to create my blog site. We are going to create this blog site using the static site generator Hugo and then host it on github pages. I know this site is mostly to document my game developer journey, but I think this is a good thing to know for game developers and plus, I learned so I want to share it.
item.content:
If you have some development skills, and are looking to create a blog site for free, this is the place for you. I am going to walk through the steps I took to create my blog site. We are going to create this blog site using the static site generator Hugo and then host it on github pages.

I know this site is mostly to document my game developer journey, but I think this is a good thing to know for game developers and plus, I learned so I want to share it.

0. Prerequisites

  1. A Github account and basic experience using git.
  2. An understanding of how to add a program to path on your operating system or knowledge on how to use your OS’s package manager.
  3. Some kind of code or text editor software.

1. Install Hugo

There are a few methods for installing Hugo on your machine. Probably the best solution is using homebrew, as it requires the least setup. If you do not have homebrew, then you can download a binary of Hugo from github releases and add the binary to your system path. See the link down below for more details.

  • How To Install Hugo
  • How to Add Binary to Path To Windows
  • How to Add Binary to Path to MacOS

Install Hugo Windows by Mike Dane

Install Hugo MacOS by Mike Dane

2. Create Hugo Project

Next we need to create a new project. Open your command line and navigate to the directory you want to create the project directory in. Then run this command. Make sure to replace <project-name> with whatever you want to call your project.

hugo new site <project-name>

This command will create a new directory in the current directory. To enter the project from the command line, run

cd <project-name>

Now that you are in the project directory, run the following command to initialize this project as a git project.

git init

Finally, add a file named .gitignore to the project directory. This file will be used to ignore files that you do not want to include in the project. Paste the following text into the file.

# Generated files by hugo
/public/
/resources/_gen/
/assets/jsconfig.json
hugo_stats.json

# Executable may be added to repository
hugo.exe
hugo.darwin
hugo.linux

# Temporary lock file while building
/.hugo_build.lock

3. Adding a theme

Now we need to add a theme to the site. If you don’t plan to modify the src code for the theme to much, the best option is to add it as a git submodule (that way you can get updates for the theme down the line with one command). A lot of themes will have commands to add the theme as a submodule. There is a list of themes on Hugo's websites . For my website, I am using the hello-friend-ng theme by Djordje Atlialp . I am going to walk through how I added that to my site.

Once in the project directory, run the following command to add the theme as a submodule.

git submodule add https://github.com/rhazdon/hugo-theme-hello-friend-ng.git themes/hello-friend-ng

You will find a config.toml in your project directory. Open that in your preferred text editor and paste the following defaults for the theme.

baseurl      = "localhost"
title        = "My Blog"
languageCode = "en-us"
theme        = "hello-friend-ng"
paginate     = 10

[params]
  dateform        = "Jan 2, 2006"
  dateformShort   = "Jan 2"
  dateformNum     = "2006-01-02"
  dateformNumTime = "2006-01-02 15:04"

  # Subtitle for home
  homeSubtitle = "A simple and beautiful blog"

  # Set disableReadOtherPosts to true in order to hide the links to other posts.
  disableReadOtherPosts = false

  # Enable sharing buttons, if you like
  enableSharingButtons = true

  # Metadata mostly used in document's head
  description = "My new homepage or blog"
  keywords = "homepage, blog"
  images = [""]

[taxonomies]
    category = "blog"
    tag      = "tags"
    series   = "series"

[languages]
  [languages.en]
    title = "Hello Friend NG"
    subtitle = "A simple theme for Hugo"
    keywords = ""
    copyright = '<a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CC BY-NC 4.0</a>'
    readOtherPosts = "Read other posts"

    [languages.en.params.logo]
      logoText = "hello friend ng"
      logoHomeLink = "/"
    # or
    #
    # path = "/img/your-example-logo.svg"
    # alt = "Your example logo alt text"

  # And you can even create generic menu
  [[menu.main]]
    identifier = "blog"
    name       = "Blog"
    url        = "/posts"

If you are using a different theme, follow the setup instructions for that theme.

4. Adding Content

Finally, the part we have been waiting for, we get to create content. To create new content with all the necessary meta tags we will use the hugo new command. To create a new blog post. Run the following command.

hugo new posts/my-first-post.md

Now if you open that new content file in a text editor, located at <project-dir>/content/posts/my-first-post.md, you will see something like this.

---
title: "My First Blog Post"
date: 2022-07-04T09:24:14-04:00
draft: true
toc: false
images:
tags:
  - untagged
---

Don’t worry if you don’t have all of this, some themes add different meta tags to posts. The important part is that at the top of your file you have a block of text surrounded with ---. Right under this block you can just start typing. All of the content is made in markdown while allows you to do simple styling. Here is a Markdown Cheatsheet get you starter.

An example of a page might look something like this.

---
title: "My First Blog Post"
date: 2022-07-04T09:24:14-04:00
draft: true
toc: false
images:
tags:
  - untagged
---

Hello this is my first blog posts. I just wanted to say hi.

## Who Am I?
Im the guy who created this blog.

5. Start the Hugo Server

Now that we have our blog site, we need to start the server. To do this, we will run the following command.

hugo server -D

Hugo server starts a server running on our local machine. The -D flag will include draft content in the site for preview. In your command line, after running that command, you should see a line that looks like this:

Web Server is available at http://localhost:1313/ (bind address 127.0.0.1)

This means that you can go to http://localhost:1313/ in your browser to see your site. You can make changes to the content and see the changes immediately.

6. Create a Repository on Github

Now that we have a site, we need to create a repository on Github. This is where you will be able to share your site with the world. To create a new repo on github, you will need an account at https://github.com. Once you are signed in you will be able to click the plus icon in the top right corner of the screen and select New Repository. From there, you you can name your repo and select the Public option. Leave everything else default or blank.

Now we need to push or local project to the github repository. To do this, we will run the following commands in the project directory.

git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git remote add origin git@github.com:<username>/<repo-name>.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

This command will stage all of the changed files, commit them to the default branch, add a remote origin for the project, set default branch’s name to main and push the main branch to the github repository.

7. Deploy to Github Pages

Now that we have a repository on Github, we need to deploy it to Github Pages. To do this we need to setup a github actions workflow. Don’t worry if you don’t know exactly what this is. It is just a way to to automatic build and deploy our website to github pages when we push our content to github. To setup a workflow up, create a new directory called .github in the project directory. Then in the .github directory, create a new directory called workflows. Then, create a new workflow file called main.yml. In that file, paste the following.

name: CI
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-18.04
    steps:
      - name: Git checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Update theme
        # (Optional)If you have the theme added as submodule, you can pull it and use the most updated version
        run: git submodule update --init --recursive

      - name: Setup hugo
        uses: peaceiris/actions-hugo@v2
        with:
          hugo-version: "0.101.0"
          extended: true

      - name: Build
        # remove --minify tag if you do not need it
        # docs: https://gohugo.io/hugo-pipes/minification/
        run: hugo --minify

      - name: Deploy
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./public
          publish_branch: gh-pages

What this action does is, on push to the main branch, checkout the code, pull the theme, install hugo in the action container, build the project, and deploy the built site to a new branch called gh-pages.

Next you need to set the base url for your site. This is the url that will be used to access your site. If you are not going to buy a domain and set it up for this, then the baseurl will be https://<username>.github.io/<repo-name>. If you do use a custom domain, then you can set the baseurl to https://<domain-name>. To set the base url, open the config.toml file in the project directory and set the baseurl to the domain you will be using.

After this is added, you can run the following command to push your code to github.

git add .
git commit -m "Added Automatic Deployment"
git push

8. Setup Github Pages on Repository

The last thing we need to do is to setup Github Pages on our repository. To do this, we will need to go the repository settings page. You can find this on your Github repository page by clicking the gear icon in the nav bar. Its the button farthest to the right. Once in the settings page, you can click the Pages tab in the left side nav. From there, under “Source” section, you can select the gh-pages branch and leave the folder set to /(root).

9. The Future / References

You can now see your site in Github Pages. To add more content to your site, follow the steps above for adding content and then to deploy it to Github Pages. Run the following commands.

git add .
git commit -m "Content Update Message/Label"
git push

Also if its easier for you to edit this files in the browser, you can press . while on the github repository page and you will be able to edit files there.

If you are interested in going further with any of the topics above, or are looking for other references, you can check out the following links.

  • Hugo Quick Start
  • Github Actions Quick Start
  • HTML Shortcodes for Hugo
  • Customizing Hugo Themes
  • Custom Domain for Github Pages
  • Deploy Github Pages Action

item.title: The plan is simple...
item.description: I have decided I want to make a change in my life. I have always loved games and game development. I have been making games by myself and with friends for about 8 years now. My plan is pursue game development as more than just a hobby. I want to document that process here. Why do I care? I hope that by sharing my journey and process that I am able to help people who are interested in developing games as a career or as a hobby.
item.content:
I have decided I want to make a change in my life. I have always loved games and game development. I have been making games by myself and with friends for about 8 years now. My plan is pursue game development as more than just a hobby. I want to document that process here.

Why do I care?

I hope that by sharing my journey and process that I am able to help people who are interested in developing games as a career or as a hobby. I also hope that I can grow a community who enjoy discussing and making games together, and that this group can be a part of the larger game dev community.

Who are you?

I’m Eric Sexton. I’m originally a self taught programmer who earned a BS in Computer Science at Purdue University Fort Wayne. I worked all through college, which is added up to 4 years of professional web development experience. I obviously enjoy video games, but I also like to dabble in cooking and mixing drinks.

What are you going to be documenting?

The main thing I will be documenting at the start will be work on my personal projects. I’m currently in the middle of trying to fully release a game I made during a game jam with a group of friends. I also hope to document game jams I do. I’m interested in maybe streaming or video documenting my game jams since so much happens in a couple of days, so look at for that. On top of that, I my dream is to run my own indie studio so hopefully I can document that road to chasing that goal.

When / Where should I look for stuff?

Obviously, this website is a good place. My goal is to start with weekly dev logs on this website, and then as I get comfortable, I want to try different types of content like video and streaming. I will announce if and when those things are coming.
